item.title: Test that license texts match SPDX plain license texts
item.description: We should have a test that each license text in _licenses is the same as the plain text license in the SPDX collection to automate the requirement described at https://github.com/github/choosealicense.com/blob/gh-pages/CONTRIBUTING.md#adding-a-licensernrn> The text of the license should match the corresponding text found in spdx/license-list-data. If there are errors there, please fix them in spdx/license-list-XML (from which the plain text version is generated) so as to minimize license text variation and make it easier for choosealicense.com to eventually consume license texts directly from SPDX.rnrnThe test could clone spdx/license-list-data and compare each license we have cataloged in this project. Many existing licenses would probably have to be marked as expected failures due to bugs in SPDX output and discrepancies in how this project has cataloged some licenses. But we should address upfront for any new license cataloged here, and continue to chip away at the existing inconsistencies."

item.title: List of languages without a colour
item.description: Continuing from #4506. 49 Proposal: Make triaging more welcoming to external contributors https://github.com/github/linguist/issues/4982 I’ve contributed on and off to linguist since 2017 and over time I’ve observed a quite frustrating pattern with issues and pull requests: legitimate issues and pull requests get labelled quite quickly as stale (30 days) and then closed (60), with no further option to reopen them.rnrnI understand that this workflow may be convenient for maintainers, but it seems discouraging in a few ways:rnrn- For a casual contributor, 60 days may be a too strict deadline for a Pull Request. It is quite frustrating to come back at a Pull Request a couple of months later (holidays or whatever reason for inactivity) to find you need to create a new one. rnrn- For issues, closing an issue just because there is no PR in 60 days hides them from people who are looking for active ways to contribute. It also tends to promote filing duplicates without reading any of the previous discussion.rnrnI think this could be improved in a way that promotes external contributions while maintaining convenience for maintainers. There are probably many good ways, but I’m thinking about something along the following lines:rnrn- Pull Requests: Do not close them automatically (or extend the grace period). There’s 73 PRs closed as Stale over a ~2 years period. A few of them were mostly ready, so the project could probably benefit from keeping them alive for a while.rnrn- Issues: Once an issue is confirmed to be a valid bug or feature request, add a label (e.g. Help Wanted) and exclude it from the Stale workflow. This label would be a great way for people looking to contribute, while making it clear to the reporter that it needs someone to work on it. Keeping them open and clearly marked also makes them more easily discoverable by users experiencing the same issue, so they can contribute to the discussion.rnrnWhat do you think?"

item.title: Prettier for JavaScript and TypeScript
item.description: IIUC, super-linter uses ESLint and Standard to format JavaScript and TypeScript code rather than Prettier. I think many developers will have an issue with this. Despite the name, Standard is not a standard. It’s developers just gave it that name. For the past few years the trend has been to use ESLint only to check for issues and to use Prettier for formatting.rnrnMost developers will be fine with most of the formatting that Standard performs. However, there is one controversial thing that it does. It enforces a space after function names in their definition. For example:rnrnjsrnfunction myName (param1, param2) {rn ...rn)rnrnrnI think you will find that almost no JavaScript developer does this. So using Standard will make this change across their code bases and they will not like it.rnrnPlease reconsider the use of Standard for JavaScript formatting and instead use Prettier, which is by far the more popular option.rn"

item.title: Support multiple views
item.description: Feature requestrnrnrnAllow refactoring small view parts into a separate view, and be able to render them into the template. These views should not be available outside the component.rnrnrnapp/components/my_component/my_component.html.erbrnapp/components/my_component/a_part.html.erbrnrnrnerbrn< Fix rendering of components that utilize `capture` in a parent view context https://github.com/github/view_component/pull/240 In Rails, when you create a form it saves a reference to the currentrntemplate object that is rendering the form. When you render a formrnbuilder helper method, like form.label inside of a child component therntemplate object will be the original template object from where the formrnbuilder was instantiated.rnrnThis means in cases where we pass a block to a form builder helper thern@output_buffer is the parent component’s output buffer. So when thatrnbuffer is overridden via .capture it’s setting the parent component’srn@output_buffer to a new, temporary buffer but it doesn’t change thernchild component that is actually rendering’s @output_buffer. Thisrnmeans the block is executed in the context of the child componentsrnactual @output_buffer and immediately writes to the buffer. Sincerncapture had nothing written to the temporary buffer, it returns thernvalue of the block call and then inserts that into the parentrncomponent’s @output_buffer.rnrnThis resolves the issue by monkey patching ActionView::Base to supportrna new child_component attribute and overriding output_buffer= to setrnits child_components output_buffer to whatever output_buffer is setrnto. With that in place, when capture is called, then #output_buffer=`rnis called which will update the child component’s output buffer to the new rntemporary buffer correctly."

item.title: Moving away from TaskCluster
item.description: TaskCluster is a CI service provided by Mozilla, and available to both Firefox development (Firefox-CI instance) and Community on Github (Community TaskCluster). It’s being widely used across some Mozilla projects, and it has its own advantages. In our case, the control over tasks, over workers for specific needs and long build time was easier to achieve working with the TaskCluster team rather than relying on other CI services.rnrnHowever, this has lead to the CI code being very specific to the project, and kind of a source of frustration for non employees trying to send patches and get involved in the project ; specifically because some of the CI parts were “hand-crafted” and triggering builds and tests requires being a “collaborator” on the Github project, which has other implications making it complicated to enable it easily to anyone. In the end, this creates an artificial barrier to contributing to this project, even though we happily run PRs manually, it is still frustrating for everyone. The issue https://github.com/mozilla/DeepSpeech/issues/3228 was an attempt to fix that, but we came to the conclusion it would be more beneficial for everyone to switch to some well known CI service and setup that is less intimidating. While TaskCluster is a great tool and has helped us a lot, we feel its limitations now makes it inappropriate for the project to stimulate and enable external contributions.rnrnWe would like to take this opportunity to also enable more contributors to hack and own the code related to CI, so discussion is open.rn"
